clean_story:
"Nature’s skyscrapers. Earth’s lungs.

The word tree comes from Old English trēow, meaning a tall plant with a single woody stem.

Most see trees as silent giants—background scenery.
But they’re living pumps, pulling water from roots to leaves faster than a straw sips soda.
A single oak can move 100 gallons a day, using tubes thinner than hair.
They’re also chemical factories, turning sunlight into sugar—fuel for insects, birds, even humans.
One beech tree’s yearly sugar output could power a child’s sprint for 30 miles.

Trees talk too.
When a giraffe chews an acacia’s leaves, the tree releases a bitter gas.
Nearby acacias detect it and flood their own leaves with toxins—warning in 10 minutes.
Underground, fungal threads act like tree internet, trading water for nutrients between species.
A dying stump can live for decades, fed by its neighbors.

The tallest, California’s Hyperion redwood, stretches 380 feet—taller than the Statue of Liberty.
The oldest, a bristlecone pine named Methuselah, has stood 4,855 years—older than the pyramids.

Three related subjects are forest communication networks, how wood becomes fossil fuel, and trees that grow metal. "
